render.tex: \title{Equation of Plane - Three point form} \\ %text Equation of a plane that passes through three given points %

reason.tex:
%text A plane that passes through three points whose vectors are $\ora{a}$, $\ora{b}$ and $\ora{c}$ is given by, %
\begin{align} (\ora{r}-\ora{a})\cdot\left[(\ora{c}-\ora{a})\times(\ora{b}-\ora{a})\right]=0 \end{align} \\
%text If $\ora{r}$ is given by $(x,y,z)$ and $\ora{a}$, $\ora{b}$ and $\ora{c}$ are given by $(x_1,y_1,z_1)$, $(x_2, y_2, z_2)$ and $(x_3, y_3, z_3)$ respectively, then the same equation in cartesian form is given by, %
\begin{align} \left\vert\begin{array}{ccc} x-x_1 & y-y_1 & z-z_1 \\ x_2-x_1 & y_2-y_1 & z_2-z_1 \\ x_3-x_1 & y_3-y_1 & z_3-z_1 \end{array}\right\vert=0 \end{align} \\
%text
The rationale behind these equations is that since $\ora{a}$, $\ora{b}$, $\ora{c}$ and $\ora{r}$ all lie on the same plane, the cross-product of displacement vectors $(\ora{b}-\ora{a})$ and $(\ora{c}-\ora{a})$ is $\perp$ to vector $(\ora{r}-\ora{a})$. %
